messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
What's the temperature here right now
Sure—so I can give you the correct current temperature, could you let me know where “here” is (a city name, ZIP code, or approximate latitude/longitude)?

No problem—could you tell me anything about where you are right now that might help narrow it down?  
For example:
• The name of a nearby city, town, or village  
• A ZIP/postal code you’ve seen on mail or signs  
• A well-known landmark (airport code, train station, mountain, beach, etc.)  
• Or, if you can, the latitude/longitude your phone or computer shows when you open a map app and tap “current location.”  

Any clue you can share will let me look up the current temperature for you.
I don't really have any more info on my location, sorry.

I’m afraid I can’t look up the current temperature without at least an approximate location. If you’re not sure where you are, here are a few quick ways to find out so we can get the weather for you:

1. Smartphone maps  
   • On iOS: Open Apple Maps → tap the arrow icon (location) → a blue dot appears; swipe up on the panel and look for the latitude/longitude, or note the city name shown.  
   • On Android/Google Maps: Open Google Maps → tap the target icon (location) → the blue dot appears; press-and-hold on the blue dot, then swipe up on the dropped-pin card to see coordinates.

2. Computer browser  
   • Open Google Maps (maps.google.com) → click the bullseye icon in the lower-right; a blue dot appears. Right-click it, choose “What’s here?”, and the coordinates show at the bottom.  
   • In most browsers, you can also type “What’s my location” or “Where am I” into a search engine and allow location access when prompted.

3. IP-based lookup  
   • Visit a site like ipinfo.io or whatismyipaddress.com—many display an estimated city/region. (Less precise, but usually enough for weather.)

4. Nearby signage  
   • Look for road signs, transit stops, or street names you can relay (e.g., “Main St. & 5th Ave., Springfield”).

Once you have even a rough idea—city, ZIP/postal code, or a pair of coordinates—just let me know and I’ll grab the current temperature for you.
I can't get any useful info from that either.

I understand—that can be frustrating. Unfortunately, without at least a rough idea of where you are (even something as broad as the nearest city or ZIP code), I don’t have any way to look up accurate local weather data for you. If you do manage to learn even a general location later, just let me know and I’ll be happy to get the current temperature for you right away.
